Dear Mr. Hogue:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Claudia Triestram at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
A male has been sneaking into resident's room every night at the facility.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident A was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 3, 2020.
Resident A said Resident B has been sneaking into her room for the past four or five
weeks about once per week. Resident A said Resident B will climb into South Bluff
through Resident C’s window and then cross the hallway and come into her room.
Resident A said Resident B will usually come around 11pm and then leave around
5am. Resident A said she and Resident B will spend time talking and listening to
music. Resident A said they are always fully clothed and denied anything sexual
happening. Resident A said when she hears staff near her door for a room check
Resident B will hide under the bed or in the closet and staff have never seen him.
Resident A said when he leaves, he jumps out her window. Resident A said
Resident C is aware of all the times that Resident B has snuck into South Bluff and
has helped him do so on several occasions. Resident A said the South Bluff
overnight staff always come and open her door and check on her throughout the
night, however she is unaware of the exact timeframes this occurs, stating “I don’t
know when, but a lot”.
Resident B was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 3, 2020.
Resident B said he has snuck out of Indian River and into South Bluff at least two
different times. Resident B said he goes out of his window and then into the window
of the bedroom across from Resident A in South Bluff. Resident B said he leaves
pillows and blankets stuffed in his bed at Indian River so that staff think he is in his
bed when they do a room check. Resident B said he has stayed all night at South
Bluff spending time with Resident A and Resident C. Resident B said he will jump
out of Resident A’s window when he is leaving South Bluff. Resident B said he
leaves a card wedged in the doorjamb of the door next to his bedroom at Indian
River so that it does not locked and he sneaks back into the house through that door
and back into his bedroom. Resident B said he was caught one time outside his
window by staff but otherwise has never been seen or caught while inside South
Bluff. Resident B said he is able to hide in the closet or under the bed when he and
Resident A hear staff coming to do a room check. Resident B said while in Resident
A’s room he normally sits by the closet because he and Resident A do not know
when a staff might come into the room and that way he is hidden. Resident B said
he has never met Resident A or Resident C outside, and it has always been him
sneaking into South Bluff.
Resident C was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 3, 2020.
Resident C said she has not participated in sneaking Resident B into South Bluff.
Resident C said she has not gone into Resident A’s room during the night to talk or
spend time with Resident B and Resident A. Resident C denied knowing anything
3

about Resident B sneaking into South Bluff. Resident C said the overnight staff at
South Bluff randomly check on her throughout the night.
Supervisor Z was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 3, 2020.
Supervisor Z said all staff are trained the same for overnight shifts. Supervisor Z said
staff are told they must complete room checks within 15 minutes at variable
intervals. Supervisor Z said that staff are to look into rooms but are not supposed to
go into the bedrooms due to a lack of cameras in the bedroom. Supervisor Z said
that all staff are to see a body part or see breathing in order to verify the resident is
actually in the bed. Supervisor Z said he does not do additional video checks to
ensure the room checks are being completed appropriately.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on September 30, 2020. Staff 1 said she
has been working the overnight shifts for a couple of months and received full
training on the overnight responsibilities. Staff 1 said she is to do room checks at
varying intervals not to exceed fifteen minutes. Staff 1 said she is required to see a
body part in the bed to ensure the youth is in the bed. Staff 1 said Resident A had
various patterns overnight and at times would be awake all night, other times sleep
all night, and then at times be awake on and off throughout the night. Staff 1 said it
was not unusual to do a room check on Resident A and find her awake in her room.
Staff 1 said on nights when Resident A would be awake she would come in and out
of her room, however Staff 1 said even if she saw Resident A in the hallway or gave
her a drink of water she would still go down to Resident A bedroom and do a room
check in her bedroom. Staff 1 said she never suspected Resident B was in the
house and never saw him when she did her room checks.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on October 12, 2020. Staff 2 said she was
hired and trained as an overnight staff. Staff 2 said she does room checks within
fifteen minutes at varying times for each of the residents. Staff 2 said if a resident
comes out of their room she still goes and does a check of them in their room. Staff
2 said she was trained not to go into the bedrooms of any of the residents because
there are no cameras in the bedrooms. Staff 2 said she goes to the bedrooms and
looks into the room and ensures a resident is in the room by viewing a body part.
Staff 2 said there were nights with Resident A would not go to sleep and would sit in
her room quietly. Staff 2 said it was not unusual for Resident A to have sleepless
nights every once and a while. Staff 2 said she had no knowledge of Resident B
sneaking into South Bluff until after it was brought up on September 3, 2020.
Director of Maintenance was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 3, 2020. Director of Maintenance said the facility alarms do not work and
have not in “a long time”. Director of Maintenance said the company that serviced
the alarms went out of business and Teaching Family Homes is looking for a new
security company to either service the current alarm system or install a new system.
Documents Reviewed:
 Room Check Policy which states the following:
4

1. When conducting a room check, staff will disarm alarms in the
hallways, and disarm any door alarms prior to checking on the youth in
their bedroom. For programs equipped with outside motion detectors,
these shall remain on at all times from lights out until wake-up.
2. Staff shall enter each bedroom and visually observe/identify the youth.
Identification is defined as seeing the assigned youth’s face.
3. Staff shall record the youth’s status on the Room Check Sheet
4. Staff shall immediately re-arm all door alarms following the completion
of each room check, and re-arm the general hallway alarms where
applicable.
5. Staff shall immediately notify the on-call supervisor/consultant of any
significant event(s) as described in the “Reporting of Significant
Events” list.
6. The on-call supervisor shall notify the Residential Director of any
significant event.
7. Child Protective Services, DCWL or other applicable party shall be
notified of any event determined to suspect neglect or abuse to any
resident. (See “Reporting of Significant Events” List
 Video Footage of South Bluff on 8/25/2020 and 9/2/2020. The video footage
shows Resident B in South Bluff sneaking in and out of Resident A and
Resident C’s rooms. The footage shows Staff 1 and Staff 2 doing room
checks as documented on room check logs at varying intervals never
exceeding fifteen minutes.
 Safety Plan for Resident A, Resident B, and Resident C that was developed
on September 3, 2020 in response to learning that Resident B was sneaking
out of Indian River and into South Bluff.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
5

ANALYSIS: According to interviews, video footage reviewed, and documents
reviewed South Bluff staff were doing appropriate room checks
of Resident A and Resident C. Resident A denied ever telling
any staff and stated staff never knew Resident B was in her
room during their room checks. The Staff at South Bluff did their
room checks appropriately. Indian River is being cited in a
companion investigation for not knowing that Resident B was
not in his room when they conducted their room checks.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The agency policy for Room Check, dated 7/24/2020, and specific to alarms states:
1. When conducting a room check, staff will disarm alarms in the hallways, and
disarm any door alarms prior to checking on the youth in their bedroom. For
programs equipped with outside motion detectors, these shall remain on at all
times from lights out until wake-up.
4. Staff she immediately re-am all door alarms following the completion of each room
check, and re-arm the general hallway alarms where applicable.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program Statement
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing resident’s
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
ANALYSIS: The agency policy for Room Checks specifically addresses the
arming and disarming of alarms. However, according to staff
and the Director of Maintenance, the alarm system does not
work and has not worked in about 8 months.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
